If a function is locally integrable, then it is integrable on any compact set.

type:
∀ {X : Type u_1} {E : Type u_3} [inst : MeasurableSpace X] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace X] [inst_2 : NormedAddCommGroup E]
  {f : X → E} {μ : MeasureTheory.Measure X} {k : Set X},
  MeasureTheory.LocallyIntegrable f → IsCompact k → MeasureTheory.IntegrableOn f k
name: MeasureTheory.LocallyIntegrable.integrableOn_isCompact
docString: If a function is locally integrable, then it is integrable on any compact set.

For a holomorphic function `f` on an open set `U` in the complex plane, if `c` is a point in `U`, `R` is the radius of a disk containing `c` that is contained in `U`, and `w₀` is a point in the disk, then the derivative of `f` at `w₀` equals the value of the integral of `f(z)` times `(z - w₀)⁻¹` over the circle of radius `R` around `c`, multiplied by `iπ⁻¹`.

type:
∀ {E : Type u} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ℂ E] [inst_2 : CompleteSpace E] {U : Set ℂ},
  IsOpen U →
    ∀ {c w₀ : ℂ} {R : ℝ} {f : ℂ → E},
      Metric.closedBall c R ⊆ U →
        DifferentiableOn ℂ f U →
          w₀ ∈ Metric.ball c R →
            ((2 * ↑Real.pi * Complex.I)⁻¹ • ∮ (z : ℂ) in C(c, R), ((z - w₀) ^ 2)⁻¹ • f z) = deriv f w₀
name: Complex.two_pi_I_inv_smul_circleIntegral_sub_sq_inv_smul_of_differentiable
docString: For a holomorphic function `f` on an open set `U` in the complex plane, if `c` is a point in `U`, `R` is the radius of a disk containing `c` that is contained in `U`, and `w₀` is a point in the disk, then the derivative of `f` at `w₀` equals the value of the integral of `f(z)` times `(z - w₀)⁻¹` over the circle of radius `R` around `c`, multiplied by `iπ⁻¹`.

This theorem states that for any complex-valued function `f` and any complex number `c`, the contour (or line) integral of `f` around the circle centered at `c` with radius 0 is always 0. More formally, `∮ (z : ℂ) in C(c, 0), f z = 0`, where `C(c, 0)` is the circle centered at `c` with radius 0, `ℂ` denotes the set of complex numbers, and `E` is any normed add-commutative group that is also a normed space over the complex numbers.

type:
∀ {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ℂ E] (f : ℂ → E) (c : ℂ),
  (∮ (z : ℂ) in C(c, 0), f z) = 0
name: circleIntegral.integral_radius_zero
docString: This theorem states that for any complex-valued function `f` and any complex number `c`, the contour (or line) integral of `f` around the circle centered at `c` with radius 0 is always 0. More formally, `∮ (z : ℂ) in C(c, 0), f z = 0`, where `C(c, 0)` is the circle centered at `c` with radius 0, `ℂ` denotes the set of complex numbers, and `E` is any normed add-commutative group that is also a normed space over the complex numbers.

Integral $\oint_{|z-c|=R} \frac{dz}{z-w} = 2πi$ whenever $|w-c| < R$.

type: ∀ {c w : ℂ} {R : ℝ}, w ∈ Metric.ball c R → (∮ (z : ℂ) in C(c, R), (z - w)⁻¹) = 2 * ↑Real.pi * Complex.I
name: circleIntegral.integral_sub_inv_of_mem_ball
docString: Integral $\oint_{|z-c|=R} \frac{dz}{z-w} = 2πi$ whenever $|w-c| < R$.

Given an integrable real-valued function on a topological space, there exists an integrable, upper semicontinuous function with values in the extended real numbers whose integral is arbitrarily close to that of the original function, and which is almost everywhere greater than negative infinity.

type:
∀ {α : Type u_1} [inst : TopologicalSpace α] [inst_1 : MeasurableSpace α] [inst_2 : BorelSpace α]
  {μ : MeasureTheory.Measure α} [inst_3 : μ.WeaklyRegular] [inst_4 : MeasureTheory.SigmaFinite μ] (f : α → ℝ),
  MeasureTheory.Integrable f μ →
    ∀ {ε : ℝ},
      0 < ε →
        ∃ g,
          (∀ (x : α), g x < ↑(f x)) ∧
            UpperSemicontinuous g ∧
              MeasureTheory.Integrable (fun x => (g x).toReal) μ ∧
                (∀ᵐ (x : α) ∂μ, ⊥ < g x) ∧ ∫ (x : α), f x ∂μ < ∫ (x : α), (g x).toReal ∂μ + ε
name: MeasureTheory.exists_upperSemicontinuous_lt_integral_gt
docString: Given an integrable real-valued function on a topological space, there exists an integrable, upper semicontinuous function with values in the extended real numbers whose integral is arbitrarily close to that of the original function, and which is almost everywhere greater than negative infinity.

This theorem is known as the Cauchy formula for the derivative of a holomorphic function. It states that for any normed additive commutative group `E`, any normed space over `ℂ` with `E` as base, and any complete space `E`, given an open set `U` in the complex plane, complex numbers `c` and `w₀`, a real number `R`, and a function `f` from complex numbers to `E`, if the closed ball centered at `c` with radius `R` is a subset of `U` and `f` is differentiable on `U` and `w₀` is in the open ball centered at `c` with radius `R`, then the integral of `f z` divided by `(z - w₀)²` around the circle centered at `c` with radius `R`, scaled by the multiplicative inverse of `2πi`, equals the derivative of `f` at `w₀`. This is a crucial property of holomorphic functions and serves as the foundation for many results in complex analysis.

type:
∀ {E : Type u} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ℂ E] [inst_2 : CompleteSpace E] {U : Set ℂ},
  IsOpen U →
    ∀ {c w₀ : ℂ} {R : ℝ} {f : ℂ → E},
      Metric.closedBall c R ⊆ U →
        DifferentiableOn ℂ f U →
          w₀ ∈ Metric.ball c R →
            ((2 * ↑Real.pi * Complex.I)⁻¹ • ∮ (z : ℂ) in C(c, R), ((z - w₀) ^ 2)⁻¹ • f z) = deriv f w₀
name: Complex.two_pi_I_inv_smul_circleIntegral_sub_sq_inv_smul_of_differentiable
docString: This theorem is known as the Cauchy formula for the derivative of a holomorphic function. It states that for any normed additive commutative group `E`, any normed space over `ℂ` with `E` as base, and any complete space `E`, given an open set `U` in the complex plane, complex numbers `c` and `w₀`, a real number `R`, and a function `f` from complex numbers to `E`, if the closed ball centered at `c` with radius `R` is a subset of `U` and `f` is differentiable on `U` and `w₀` is in the open ball centered at `c` with radius `R`, then the integral of `f z` divided by `(z - w₀)²` around the circle centered at `c` with radius `R`, scaled by the multiplicative inverse of `2πi`, equals the derivative of `f` at `w₀`. This is a crucial property of holomorphic functions and serves as the foundation for many results in complex analysis.

Any integrable function can be approximated by bounded continuous functions,
version in terms of `∫`.

type:
∀ {α : Type u_1} [inst : MeasurableSpace α] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace α] [inst_2 : T4Space α] [inst_3 : BorelSpace α]
  {E : Type u_2} [inst_4 : NormedAddCommGroup E] {μ : MeasureTheory.Measure α} [inst_5 : NormedSpace ℝ E]
  [inst_6 : MeasureTheory.Measure.WeaklyRegular μ] {f : α → E},
  MeasureTheory.Integrable f → ∀ {ε : ℝ}, 0 < ε → ∃ g, ∫ (x : α), ‖f x - g x‖ ∂μ ≤ ε ∧ MeasureTheory.Integrable ⇑g
name: MeasureTheory.Integrable.exists_boundedContinuous_integral_sub_le
docString:
Any integrable function can be approximated by bounded continuous functions,
version in terms of `∫`.

Any integrable function can be approximated by bounded continuous functions,
version in terms of `∫⁻`.

type:
∀ {α : Type u_1} [inst : MeasurableSpace α] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace α] [inst_2 : T4Space α] [inst_3 : BorelSpace α]
  {E : Type u_2} [inst_4 : NormedAddCommGroup E] {μ : MeasureTheory.Measure α} [inst_5 : NormedSpace ℝ E]
  [inst_6 : MeasureTheory.Measure.WeaklyRegular μ] {f : α → E},
  MeasureTheory.Integrable f →
    ∀ {ε : ENNReal}, ε ≠ 0 → ∃ g, ∫⁻ (x : α), ↑‖f x - g x‖₊ ∂μ ≤ ε ∧ MeasureTheory.Integrable ⇑g
name: MeasureTheory.Integrable.exists_boundedContinuous_lintegral_sub_le
docString:
Any integrable function can be approximated by bounded continuous functions,
version in terms of `∫⁻`.

If a function is locally integrable, then it is integrable on an open neighborhood of any
compact set.

type:
∀ {X : Type u_1} {E : Type u_3} [inst : MeasurableSpace X] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace X] [inst_2 : NormedAddCommGroup E]
  {f : X → E} {μ : MeasureTheory.Measure X},
  MeasureTheory.LocallyIntegrable f →
    ∀ {k : Set X}, IsCompact k → ∃ u, IsOpen u ∧ k ⊆ u ∧ MeasureTheory.IntegrableOn f u

docString:
If a function is locally integrable, then it is integrable on an open neighborhood of any
compact set.

A continuous function with compact support is integrable on the whole space.

type:
∀ {X : Type u_1} {E : Type u_3} [inst : MeasurableSpace X] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace X] [inst_2 : NormedAddCommGroup E]
  {f : X → E} {μ : MeasureTheory.Measure X} [inst_3 : OpensMeasurableSpace X]
  [inst_4 : MeasureTheory.IsFiniteMeasureOnCompacts μ], Continuous f → HasCompactSupport f → MeasureTheory.Integrable f
name: Continuous.integrable_of_hasCompactSupport
docString: A continuous function with compact support is integrable on the whole space.

A holomorphic function on a compact connected complex manifold is constant.

type:
∀ {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ℂ E] {F : Type u_2} [inst_2 : NormedAddCommGroup F]
  [inst_3 : NormedSpace ℂ F] {H : Type u_3} [inst_4 : TopologicalSpace H] {I : ModelWithCorners ℂ E H}
  [inst_5 : ModelWithCorners.Boundaryless I] {M : Type u_4} [inst_6 : TopologicalSpace M] [inst_7 : CompactSpace M]
  [inst_8 : ChartedSpace H M] [inst_9 : SmoothManifoldWithCorners I M] [inst_10 : PreconnectedSpace M] {f : M → F},
  MDifferentiable I (modelWithCornersSelf ℂ F) f → ∀ (a b : M), f a = f b
name: MDifferentiable.apply_eq_of_compactSpace
docString: A holomorphic function on a compact connected complex manifold is constant.

A holomorphic function on a compact complex manifold is locally constant.

type:
∀ {E : Type u_1} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace ℂ E] {F : Type u_2} [inst_2 : NormedAddCommGroup F]
  [inst_3 : NormedSpace ℂ F] {H : Type u_3} [inst_4 : TopologicalSpace H] {I : ModelWithCorners ℂ E H}

If a function is integrable, then the integral of its truncated versions converges to the
integral of the whole function.

type:
∀ {α : Type u_1} {m : MeasurableSpace α} {μ : MeasureTheory.Measure α} {f : α → ℝ},
  MeasureTheory.Integrable f →
    Filter.Tendsto (fun A => ∫ (x : α), ProbabilityTheory.truncation f A x ∂μ) Filter.atTop (nhds (∫ (x : α), f x ∂μ))
name: ProbabilityTheory.tendsto_integral_truncation
docString:
If a function is integrable, then the integral of its truncated versions converges to the
integral of the whole function.

In a locally compact space, any integrable function can be approximated by compactly supported
continuous functions, version in terms of `∫⁻`.

type:
∀ {α : Type u_1} [inst : MeasurableSpace α] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace α] [inst_2 : T4Space α] [inst_3 : BorelSpace α]
  {E : Type u_2} [inst_4 : NormedAddCommGroup E] {μ : MeasureTheory.Measure α} [inst_5 : NormedSpace ℝ E]
  [inst_6 : WeaklyLocallyCompactSpace α] [inst_7 : MeasureTheory.Measure.Regular μ] {f : α → E},
  MeasureTheory.Integrable f →
    ∀ {ε : ENNReal},
      ε ≠ 0 → ∃ g, HasCompactSupport g ∧ ∫⁻ (x : α), ↑‖f x - g x‖₊ ∂μ ≤ ε ∧ Continuous g ∧ MeasureTheory.Integrable g
name: MeasureTheory.Integrable.exists_hasCompactSupport_lintegral_sub_le

In a locally compact space, any integrable function can be approximated by compactly supported
continuous functions, version in terms of `∫⁻`.

A single function is uniformly integrable.

type:
∀ {α : Type u_1} {β : Type u_2} {ι : Type u_3} {m : MeasurableSpace α} (μ : MeasureTheory.Measure α)
  [inst : NormedAddCommGroup β] {p : ENNReal} [inst_1 : Subsingleton ι],
  1 ≤ p → p ≠ ⊤ → ∀ {f : ι → α → β}, (∀ (i : ι), MeasureTheory.Memℒp (f i) p) → MeasureTheory.UnifIntegrable f p μ
name: MeasureTheory.unifIntegrable_subsingleton
docString: A single function is uniformly integrable.
